articles.headline: Inside Yelp’s Six-Year Grudge Against Google
articles.snippet: Once courted, then spurned, the smaller rival sought revenge for years. Now Europe’s regulators give it reason to cheer.
articles.abstract: Once courted, then spurned, the smaller rival sought revenge for years. Now Europe’s regulators give it reason to cheer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeremy Stoppelman, chief executive of Yelp, the local search and reviewing site, would like this article to be focused on his company’s growth, or on how its reviews help independent businesses, or on pretty much anything besides what it is about: how Yelp became Google’s most tenacious pest.

articles.headline: American Companies Still Make Aluminum. In Iceland.
articles.snippet: The Trump administration blames China for the decline of aluminum production in the U.S. But where has it really gone?
articles.abstract: The Trump administration blames China for the decline of aluminum production in the U.S. But where has it really gone?
articles.lead_paragraph: REYDARFJORDUR, Iceland — Where did the United States’ aluminum smelters go?

articles.headline: ‘I Want This to Get Over’: After Congressional Shooting, Complex Grief for a Gunman’s Widow
articles.snippet: Suzanne Hodgkinson, whose husband opened fire at a baseball practice, joins others who face a wrenching challenge after a relative commits a mass shooting: mourning someone reviled by many.
articles.abstract: Suzanne Hodgkinson, whose husband opened fire at a baseball practice, joins others who face a wrenching challenge after a relative commits a mass shooting: mourning someone reviled by many.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, Ill. — He flung dishes at his wife, roared at the television, erupted during an outing at a local brewery. Suzanne Hodgkinson became so concerned with her husband’s growing anger that she wrote to his doctor asking for help.

articles.headline: In a Desperate Syrian City, a Test of Trump’s Policies
articles.snippet: Tabqa was liberated from ISIS in May, but it still has no basic services and many rotting corpses. The U.S. is sending aid, but it’s not in the business of rebuilding.
articles.abstract: Tabqa was liberated from ISIS in May, but it still has no basic services and many rotting corpses. The U.S. is sending aid, but it’s not in the business of rebuilding.
articles.lead_paragraph: TABQA, Syria — The young man unburdened himself about the dark years of living under the Islamic State as a crowd of curious onlookers gathered in front of a weathered storefront in the town marketplace.

articles.headline: Counseled by Industry, Not Staff, E.P.A. Chief Is Off to a Blazing Start
articles.snippet: Much of President Trump’s policy agenda is mired in delay, but Scott Pruitt has already achieved a major regulatory rollback.
articles.abstract: Much of President Trump’s policy agenda is mired in delay, but Scott Pruitt has already achieved a major regulatory rollback.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the four months since he took office as the Environmental Protection Agency’s administrator, Scott Pruitt has moved to undo, delay or otherwise block more than 30 environmental rules, a regulatory rollback larger in scope than any other over so short a time in the agency’s 47-year history, according to experts in environmental law.

articles.headline: The South Park Commons Fills a Hole in the Tech Landscape
articles.snippet: The Bay Area tech scene has start-up incubators and hacker spaces. But what do you do when you want to figure out your next move?
articles.abstract: The Bay Area tech scene has start-up incubators and hacker spaces. But what do you do when you want to figure out your next move?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ruchi Sanghvi was the first female engineer at Facebook, where she helped create the news feed that now serves as the primary window into the world’s largest social network. Then she built a start-up of her own and sold it to another rising Silicon Valley company, Dropbox, becoming one of its first female executives. But as she left Dropbox in 2014, she didn’t know what she would do next.

articles.headline: Trump Foot Soldier Sidelined Under Glare of Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: Michael D. Cohen, a former personal injury lawyer, worked his way up to an office at Trump Tower. Now he’s further from the family fold and entangled in investigations.
articles.abstract: Michael D. Cohen, a former personal injury lawyer, worked his way up to an office at Trump Tower. Now he’s further from the family fold and entangled in investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over a decade ago, Donald J. Trump was locked in conflict with a group of apartment owners who had taken control of the condominium board at his new glass tower across from the United Nations. Faced with accusations of financial impropriety and an affront to his authority, Mr. Trump turned to Michael D. Cohen, a former personal injury lawyer who helped run a taxi fleet.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, William K. Rashbaum and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Pinterest Wants to Show Advertisers It Can Run With the Big Dogs
articles.snippet: The site, which made a splash at Cannes, has 175 million active users and is eager to make its case that its connection to users offers unique potential.
articles.abstract: The site, which made a splash at Cannes, has 175 million active users and is eager to make its case that its connection to users offers unique potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the recent advertising conference in Cannes, France, Pinterest announced its presence with zeal and whimsy.

articles.headline: Hackers Find ‘Ideal Testing Ground’ for Attacks: Developing Countries
articles.snippet: Often the best way to see if a cyberweapon works is to try it out in a country without the best digital defenses, as recent attacks have indicated.
articles.abstract: Often the best way to see if a cyberweapon works is to try it out in a country without the best digital defenses, as recent attacks have indicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The attack had the hallmarks of something researchers had dreaded for years: malicious software using artificial intelligence that could lead to a new digital arms race in which A.I.-driven defenses battled A.I.-driven offenses while humans watched from the sidelines.

articles.headline: Program to Spur Low-Income Housing Is Keeping Cities Segregated
articles.snippet: In Houston and in other cities, efforts to build low-income homes in wealthy, majority white neighborhoods have stalled.
articles.abstract: In Houston and in other cities, efforts to build low-income homes in wealthy, majority white neighborhoods have stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A mural on the wall of an elementary school here proclaimed, “All the world is all of us,” but the hundreds of people packing the auditorium one night were determined to stop a low-income housing project from coming to their upscale neighborhood.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Yamiche Alcindor and Agustin Armendariz

articles.headline: Independent Press Is Under Siege as Freedom Rings
articles.snippet: How can America have a feel-good birthday when one of the pillars of our 241-year-old republic is under near-daily assault from the highest levels of the government?
articles.abstract: How can America have a feel-good birthday when one of the pillars of our 241-year-old republic is under near-daily assault from the highest levels of the government?

articles.headline: Wealthy Qatar Weathers Siege, but Personal and Political Costs Grow
articles.snippet: With its immense riches, Qatar can withstand the effects of a blockade. But the longer the dispute lasts, the more likely it is to destabilize the region.
articles.abstract: With its immense riches, Qatar can withstand the effects of a blockade. But the longer the dispute lasts, the more likely it is to destabilize the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — A young business executive had to cancel a $150,000 family vacation in Saudi Arabia. Another woman grumbled that deliveries of designer fashions from the internet store Net-a-Porter were taking several days longer to arrive.

articles.headline: Trump Warns China He Is Willing to Pressure North Korea on His Own
articles.snippet: The president’s warning, after a series of tough measures aimed at China, shows how he and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, are reassessing their approach to each other.
articles.abstract: The president’s warning, after a series of tough measures aimed at China, shows how he and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, are reassessing their approach to each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, frustrated by China’s unwillingness to lean on North Korea, has told the Chinese leader that the United States is prepared to act on its own in pressuring the nuclear-armed government in Pyongyang, according to senior administration officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: Central Americans, ‘Scared of What’s Happening’ in U.S., Stay Put
articles.snippet: While some of President Trump’s most ambitious plans to tighten the border remain a long way off, his hard-line approach to immigration seems to have reduced the flow of Central American migrants.
articles.abstract: While some of President Trump’s most ambitious plans to tighten the border remain a long way off, his hard-line approach to immigration seems to have reduced the flow of Central American migrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHOLOMA, Honduras — His bags were packed, and the smuggler was ready. If all went well, Eswin Josué Fuentes figured he and his 10-year-old daughter would slip into the United States within days.

articles.headline: Dispute Over British Baby’s Fate Draws In Pope and U.S. President
articles.snippet: British and European courts have ruled that a hospital can turn off life support for Charlie Gard, an infant with a rare genetic disorder.
articles.abstract: British and European courts have ruled that a hospital can turn off life support for Charlie Gard, an infant with a rare genetic disorder.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Charlie Gard, who turns 11 months old on Tuesday, was born with an extremely rare genetic disease. He is blind and deaf, and he cannot breathe or move on his own. He suffers from persistent epileptic seizures.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Sewell Chan
